header.title: Outsourcing
header.subtitle: Technical specification for project tasks to be outsourced
header.abstract: Integration of proofing tools with commercial applications like Adobe InDesign and Microsoft Office is very time consuming and errouneous without experience and former practice. It has thus been decided as the most cost-effective solution to outsource these tasks. — This document describes exactly what is being outsourced, and the technical specifications for the deliverables. It also specifies exactly how the offer should be divided into independent components, and variants thereof.

section.title: Outsourced tasks
section.p: The outsourced tasks can be summarized in the following table (throughout the document, the languages are specified using ISO 639-2 codes: sme = North Sámi, smj = Lule Sámi).

tr.td: Microsoft Office 2000 and newer (running on Windows 2000 and newer)
Microsoft Office 2004 and newer (running on MacOS X 10.3 and newer)

section.note: Should we also include OpenOffice.org in the table? That is, are we sure we can make it ourselves if we don't include it? One argument pro not including it, would be that we have at least one tool set over which we have complete control (barring the Xerox tools, that is). The second question is: should we also include a hyphenator for the OOo version?

section.title: Adobe InDesign
section.p: The Divvun project will outsource the integration of a sme hyphenator, and possibly the whole making of the hyphenator. In the latter case, the Divvun project will provide the language-specific algorithm, and of course be responsible for testing the linguistic correctness of the deliverable.
section.note: We need to contact the most important users, and check which version they are using or will be using. There's no use in requiring the contractor to test against an older version than needed, it will only add costs to the project.

section.title: Microsoft Office
section.p: The Divvun project will outsource the making and the integration of the proofing tools for MS Office, based on the computational linguistic models developed by the project.
